definition.name: NXbeam_path
definition.doc:
A beam path consisting of one or more optical elements.
NXbeam_path is used in NXopt to describe the beam path, i.e. the arrangement of optical elements between the excitation source and the sample, or between the sample and the detector unit.
To describe the order of the elements, use 'order(NXtransformations)', where each element's position points to the preceding element via '@depends_on'. Special case beam splitter: A beam splitter is a device which separates the beam into two or more beams. If such a device is part of the beam path use two or more NXbeam_paths to describe the beam paths after the beam splitter. In this case, in the dependency chain of the new beam paths, the first elements each point to the beam splitter, as this is the previous element.
Describe the relevant optical elements in the beam path by using the appropriate base classes. You may use as many elements as needed, also several elements of the same type as long as each element has its own name.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: Entry point of the dependency chain defined by the NXtransformations field, i.e. a link to the last element in the beam path. Example: /entry/instrument/beam_path/detector.

group.doc: Specify the order of the optical elements by defining a dependency chain. For each element, a '@depends_on' attribute should be used to state the position of the element in the beam path by pointing to the previous element. For the very first element, use the string "." instead.

field.name: AXISNAME
field.doc: For each element in the beam path, one such field must exist with a '@depends_on' attribute defined to specify its position in the beam path. Note that also 'NXopt/ENTRY/INSTRUMENT/sample_stage' and windows ('NXopt/ENTRY/INSTRUMENT/sample_stage/entry_window' and 'NXopt/ENTRY/INSTRUMENT/sample_stage/exit_window') may be added to the dependency chain, i.e. may have an entry in this class even if they are not described in the beam path. ELEMENT is a place holder for the name of an optical beam path element. Note that the name of this field must be exactly the same as the element's field name.

attribute.name: depends_on
attribute.doc: Add a link to the previous beam path element.

group.doc: Excitation source. One or more may be needed (e.g. two for a pump-probe setup with one pump and one probe beam). Depending on the source type, different properties are relevant, which are provided through the respective base class (e.g. use NXopt_source for lamps or lasers, NXchem_source for chemical reaction etc.). Some base classes are incomplete (NXchem_source, NXbio_source); the expertise of the respective communities is needed.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: Use this field to point to the previous optical element.

field.name: type
field.doc: Type of excitation source.

field.name: lifespan
field.doc: Lifespan of the excitation (typically provided in hours).

field.name: measure_time
field.doc: How many hours has the lamp been used?

field.name: excitation_wavelength
field.doc: Wavelengths or energy vector of the excitation source. This can be a single value or a spectrum, depending on the type of experiment.

field.name: beam_profile
field.doc: Two- or three-dimensional beam profile.

field.name: peak_power
field.doc: Power of one light pulse if the source is a pulsed source.

field.name: cw
field.doc: Is the excitation source continuous wave (CW)?

field.name: cw_power
field.doc: Power of CW beam.

field.name: bandwidth
field.doc: FWHM bandwidth of the excitation source.

field.name: coherence_length
field.doc: Coherence length.

field.name: divergence
field.doc: Divergence of the excitation beam.

group.doc: Use this field to describe a simple pinhole (round geometry). Define its dimension using 'diameter'. For more complex geometries, 'NXaperture' should be used.
Use this field to describe a simple slit (rectangular geometry). Define its dimensions using 'x_gap' and 'y_gap'. For more complex geometries, 'NXaperture' should be used.

group.name: aperture_NUMBER
group.doc: Use this field to describe an aperture. To specify a window, use the field 'window_NUMBER(NXaperture)'.

group.name: window_NUMBER
group.doc: A window, e.g. an entry or exit window of a cryostat.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: Use this field to point to the previous optical element.

field.name: material
field.doc: The material of the window.

field.name: other_material
field.doc: If you specified 'other' as material, decsribe here what it is.

field.name: thickness
field.doc: Thickness of the window

field.name: orientation_angle
field.doc: Angle of the window normal (outer) vs. the substrate normal (similar to the angle of incidence).

field.name: reference_data_link
field.doc: If reference data were measured add a link to the NeXus file where they are described.

group.doc: A device that reduces the intensity of a beam by attenuation.

field.name: attenuator_transmission
field.doc: The transmitted intensity divided by the incident intensity.

field.name: attenuation
field.doc: Attenuation of the attenuator in dB.

attribute.name: units
attribute.doc: Unit of the measured data is not covered by NXDL units state here which unit was used.

group.doc: Input and output aperture of the attenuator.
Geometry (shape, size etc.) of the attenuator.
A diffraction grating. Define relevant parameters in the corresponding fields, e.g. order of diffration (diffraction_order) or angular dispersion (angular_dispersion).

field.name: type
field.doc: Define the type of the grating.

field.name: angular_dispersion
field.doc: Dispersion of the grating in nm/mm (or e.g. nm/mrad).

field.name: grooves
field.doc: Number of grooves per mm.

field.name: blaze_wavelength
field.doc: Blaze wavelength of the grating.

field.name: efficiency
field.doc: Efficiency curve versus wavelength or energy.

field.name: spectrum
field.doc: Spectral values, e.g. wavelength or energy. Vector of length N_spectrum.

attribute.name: units
attribute.doc: Unit of wavelength array (e.g. nanometer or Angstrom)

group.doc: A device blocking the beam in a temporal periodic pattern, e.g. a optical chopper wheel. Specify the frequency range using 'min_frequency' and 'max_frequency'.

field.name: min_frequency
field.doc: Minimum frequency in Hertz.

field.name: max_frequency
field.doc: Maximum frequency in Hertz.

field.name: frequency_resolution
field.doc: Frequency resolution in Hertz.

field.name: spectrum
field.doc: Spectral values of the monochromator, e.g. wavelength or energy values used for the measurement.

attribute.name: units
attribute.doc: Unit of wavelength array (e.g. nanometer or Angstrom)

group.doc: Diffraction grating. If two or more gratings were used, define the angular dispersion and the wavelength range (min/max wavelength) for each grating and make sure that the wavelength ranges do not overlap. The dispersion should be defined for the entire wavelength range of the experiment.

field.name: angular_dispersion
field.doc: Dispersion of the grating in nm/mm.

field.name: grating_wavelength_min
field.doc: Minimum wavelength of the grating.

field.name: grating_wavelength_max
field.doc: Maximum wavelength of the grating.

field.name: spectral_resolution
field.doc: Spectral resolution of the instrument.

group.doc: Define the width of the monochromator slit in the subfield x_gap.

field.name: fixed_slit
field.doc: Was the slit width fixed?

field.name: max_gap
field.doc: If slit width was not fixed, define the maximum slit width.
